appendix.title: Core Types
appendix.para: This appendix contains a reference of the system data types contained in Phing.

sect1.title: Excludes
sect1.para: Specifies a set of files, classes or methods to be excluded from processing.
This element has no attributes, only nested tags

table.title: Common attributes for all File, Class, Method tags

row.entry: The name of the class, method or file. This may also be specified as a pattern.

sect1.title: FileList
sect1.para: FileLists offer a way to represent a specific list of files. Unlike FileSets, FileLists may contain files that do not exist on the filesystem. Also, FileLists can represent files in a specific order -- whereas FileSets represent files in whichever order they are returned by the filesystem.

row.entry: The directory, to which the paths given in files or listfile are relative.
Comma or space-separated list of files.
A text file with one filename per line.

sect2.title: Usage Examples
sect2.para: Or you can use a listfile, which is expected to contain one filename per line:

This will grab each file as listed in ini_files.txt. This can be useful if one task compiles a list of files to process and another task needs to read in that list and perform some action to those files.

sect1.title: FileSet
sect1.para: FileSets offer an easy and straightforward way to include files. The tag supports Selectors (see ) and PatternSets (see ). Additionally, you can include/exclude files in/from a fileset using the <include>/<exclude> tags. In patterns, one asterisk (*) maps to a part of a file/directory name within a directory level. Two asterisks (**) may include above the "border" of the directory separator.

row.entry: The directory, the paths given in include/exclude are relative to.
Whether default exclusions should be used or not. Default excludes are: *~, #*#, .#*, %*%, CVS, CVS/**, .cvsignore, SCCS, SCCS/**, vssver.scc, .svn, .svn/**, ._*, .DS_Store, .darcs, .darcs/**
The case sensitivity of the file system.
Whether to expand/dereference (follow) symbolic links - set to 'true' to emulate old Phing behavior.
Comma- or space-separated list of patterns of files that must be included; all files are included when omitted.
The name of a file; each line of this file is taken to be an include pattern.
comma- or space-separated list of patterns of files that must be excluded; no files (except default excludes) are excluded when omitted.
The name of a file; each line of this file is taken to be an exclude pattern.

listitem.para: test*.xml will include test_42.xml, but it will not include test/some.xml.
test**.xml fits to test_42.xml as well as to test/bla.xml, for example.

**/*.ent.xml fits to all files that end with ent.xml in all subdirectories of the directory specified with the dir attribute of the <fileset> tag. However, it will not include any files that are directly in the base directory of the file set.

sect2.title: Usage Examples
sect2.programlisting:
<fileset dir="/etc" > <include name="httpd/**" /> <include name="php.ini" /> </fileset>
<fileset dir="/etc" > <patternset> <include name="**/*.php"/> <exclude name="**/*Test*"/> </patternset> </fileset>
sect2.para: This will include the apache configuration and PHP configuration file from /etc.

sect1.title: PatternSet
sect1.para: The PatternSet data type defines patterns that can be grouped into sets and nested into FileSets. Patterns can be specified by nested <include> or <exclude> elements.

row.entry: Comma- or space-separated list of patterns of files that must be included; all files are included when omitted.
The name of a file; each line of this file is taken to be an include pattern.
comma- or space-separated list of patterns of files that must be excluded; no files (except default excludes) are excluded when omitted.
The name of a file; each line of this file is taken to be an exclude pattern.

sect2.title: Nested tags
sect2.para: The <patternset> tag only supports <include> and <exclude>. The <include> and the <exclude> tags must have a name attribute that contains the pattern to include/exclude.

sect1.title: Path / Classpath
sect1.para: The Path data type can be used to respresent path structures. In many cases the path type will be used for nested <classpaentry> tags. E.g.
sect1.programlisting:
<path id="project.class.path"> <pathelement dir="lib/"/> <pathelement dir="ext/"/> </paentry>
<target name="blah"> <taskdef name="mytask" path="myapp.phing.tasks.MyTask"> <classpath refid="project.class.path"/> </taskdef> </target>

row.entry: A path (which contains multiple locations separated by path.separator) to add.

sect2.title: Nested tags
sect2.para: The <paentry> tag supports nested <fileset> and <dirset> tags.
